content.description: Just stuff your whole body into the chute and stem your way up the chimney to freedom. The trickiest part is negotiating the chimney at the start. After that there is a mix of crimps, slopers, and slab to get your way to the top.
content.protection: Must build your own TR anchor using webbing and locking carabiners.  Recommend using an additional sling/runner to extend the anchor off the master anchor point.
content.location: The route is located on the smaller, gum drop shaped feature to the right and in front of the South Horror Rock section of Hall of Horrors.  To reach the TR anchor spot, proceed towards the base of My Senior Project, continue up the ramp and scramble to the top of the feature depicted in the route map.

content.description:
This is a one bolt direct start to

Cactus Flower

that starts on a heavily chalked undercling before moving into a sloping pinch. Work up the pod to join the standard Cactus Flower route.

Difficult to assign a rating but the guidebook says the grade is 5.12a - 5.12d, height dependant.
content.protection:
4 bolts (3/8", 1/2" SS), bolt anchor (1/2" SS)

Gear to 2 inches for the top of the route
content.location:
10 feet right of

Cactus Flower

's normal start.

content.description: The route is a slabby face with a pair of vertical-running cracks that offer purchase for your finger tips and toes as you work your way skyward.  Its all slab with larger cracks running parallel with the ground leading to the anchor.
content.protection: Must build your own TR anchor using webbing and locking carabiners.  Recommend using a runner/sling to make an adjustable anchor point from the master anchor point.
content.location: Route located on the right must indent of the smaller, gum drop feature located right and in front of the main South Horror Rock section of Hall of Horrors.  To establish TR anchor, proceed to the base of My Senior Project and continue up the ramp and scramble to the top of the feature to build the anchor.

climbs.name: Pull My Finger, Barbara
climbs.fa: Dave Mayville, Tom Atherton & Todd Gordon, August 1990

content.description:
Start up the initial crack of

Flash Gordon

and then move slightly right on a ledge before tackling the block above on thin edges past three bolts.
content.location:
About 20 feet right of

My Senior Project

.

content.description:
Start up

Lazy Day

and head right at the slightly obvious right slanting crack. A few delicate 5.9 moves lead to easy unprotected face moves.
content.protection: pro to 2.5", bolted anchor/rap (3/8") at the top

climbs.name: Old Guys Gone Nuts, Gone to the Cops

content.description:
This seldom done toprope climbs the nice varnished face just right of

Dog Day Afternoon

and higher moves left slightly to join that route for it's finish up the top block.

The name is a playful dig on actual events in the history of Joshua Tree National Park climbing.
content.location:
Just right of

Dog Day Afternoon

on the smooth brown face.

content.description:
This is a fun route about 60 feet up the ramp from

Lazy Day

. It is a good alternative climb if you're waiting for one of the more popular routes in the Hall of Horrors area to open up. Although it only has two bolts on the route, they are placed where you need them and the crux is very well protected. Rock quality is good moving up through the jugs on this fine route.
content.protection: There are 2 bolts (3/8") on this route and no fixed belay anchor up top.  The belay for "Lazy Day" can be used.

climbs.name: Lazy Day
climbs.fa: Jim Wilson, Mike Kaeser and Phil Warrender, November 1971

content.description:
Thirty feet from the left edge of the rock is this steep finger/hand crack that passes a horizontal crack partway up. Gear belay and easy walk/scramble down a low-angled ramp off the backside (climber's left).

Although this route can be a little awkward in spots it's good fun and the short approach is hard to beat. A popular route and a good introduction to the Hall of Horrors. Three stars out of five.
content.location:
Located on the same rock as

Dog Day Afternoon

but this route is on the east face and faces directly towards the road.

content.description:
Start up a thin flake, pass a horizontal crack and then run-it-out up the featured face above to the top. The lack of protection will make this a toprope for most.

This route briefly sported a bolt on the face, making it a reasonable lead, but it was quickly chopped after learning it had been previously led (soloed).

climbs.name: Garden Angel
climbs.fa: Charles Cole, Kelly Penix and Troy Mayr, 1988

content.description:
This climbs the left arete of the leftmost rock as seen from the parking area and it lies 20' left of an obvious crack (Lazy Day).

Three bolts and balance take one up this fun little route which is a good quick hit if in the vicinity.

From the top it is possible to rap from anchors located above and to the right of this climb (recommended) or one can walk off down left(climber's).
content.protection:
3 bolts (1/2" SS), gear to 3 inches for the anchors or use the bolted anchor/rap (3/8") off to the right atop

Cactus Flower

(don't forget to set a directional for your follower).

content.description: This mungy and akward route begins just below the gumdrop shaped peak of South Horror Rock.  The route climbs up hand to fist sized cracks around the left side of the summit cap.  A belay could be made here or with well adjusted runners you could just clip the bolt on the upper half and proceed to the top in one pitch.
content.protection: The first half of the route is trad and a standard rack of cams will sufice.  The second half is simply sport with one bolt (3/8") to the top.  There are anchors just below the summit for "Dog Day Afternoon" to decend.

content.description:
The obscurity tackles the overhanging arete to the right of

Flash Gordon

's start. The route technically ends at the horizontal but could be combined with

Pull My Finger, Barbara

to the top of the rock.
content.protection: TR (gear to 3 inches might be nice)

climbs.name: Dog Day Afternoon
climbs.fa: Dave Houser and Charles Cole, February 1979

content.description:
Start in the rocky notch between the two towers and climb solid edges on nice brown rock past four bolts to a ledge (3" piece here). One more bolt and some stemming lead to the top and a bolted anchor/rap.

Note: B Regan reports in comment  “12/5/2021 - The anchor/rap bolts are currently missing. Without the rap, it is 20 feet of 5th class climbing down to the easier down climb/scramble to the west.”

A standout climb of the area that should not be missed. Three stars out of five.
content.protection:
5 bolts to anchor/rap (all 3/8"). Take a 3 inch piece for the horizontal before the last bolt.

Note: B Regan reports in comment  “12/5/2021 - The anchor/rap bolts are currently missing. Without the rap, it is 20 feet of 5th class climbing down to the easier down climb/scramble to the west.”
content.location:
This route climbs to the top of the leftmost tower visible from the road. Directly across from this route is the obvious roof crack of

Grit Roof

which climbs to the top of the right-hand tower.

climbs.name: Cactus Flower
climbs.fa: Troy Mayr and Charles Cole, February 1988

content.description:
When this route was established Joshua Tree was going through some changes as sport climbing and rap bolting were becoming common in other climbing areas although Joshua Tree was still very much a traditional area and new routes still went in ground up for the most part. This climb was done in a unique style to uphold that "ground-up ethic" - as the climber lead up to each stance a power drill was hoisted up on a toprope! These days the atmosphere is more relaxed and most people are more concerned if the finished route is a quality one, which this one is.

Three bolts are found on this route, although some additional pro is required. At the start steep lieback moves (small gear) lead to an overhanging hand traverse which will get your blood flowing. Next you must mantle up onto a stance looking at a big fall potential as your last bolt is a ways down and left of you. Once up a lunge/long reach past a final bolt into a flake concludes the hard part. A bit of easy face leads to anchors.

There is also a direct start to this -

This is Only a Test

that bumps the grade up to solid 5.12 if the regular version is not enough.
content.protection:
3 bolts (3/8" & 1/2" SS) and gear to 2 inches

2 bolt anchor/rap (1/2" SS)
content.location:
10 feet right of

Lazy Day

on the east face of the rock.
